steps.title: Rise when the president enters the room.
steps.content: Rise when the president enters the room. All seated persons will be expected to rise when the president enters the room, as a sign of respect. The president will then indicate when those who have risen may return to their seats.

steps.title: Address the president as “Mr.
steps.content: Address the president as “Mr. President” or “Madam President.” Should you have the opportunity to speak directly with the president, do not call them by their first or last name. The title of “Mr.” or “Madam” will show your respect for the office while you carry on a conversation with the president. [1] X Trustworthy Source US Department of State Official website of the U.S. Department of State Go to source

steps.title: Introduce a third party to the president.
steps.content: Introduce a third party to the president. Use the phrase “Mr./Madam President, may I present.” In the United States, the president should not be introduced to someone, as this would seem disrespectful. Always introduce the third person to the president. [2] X Research source For example, be sure to say, “Mr./Madam President, may I present my son Billy.” Do not say, “Billy, I want you to meet the president.”

steps.title: Announce the president using his or her title.
steps.content: Announce the president using his or her title. If you are given an opportunity to announce the president—for example, before they deliver a speech—announce the president to onlookers as “the president of the United States.” [3] X Research source So, if you’re announcing the current president, you could say: “Let me announce the president of the United States, Joe Biden."

steps.title: Address the envelope to “The President.”
steps.content: Address the envelope to “The President.” In written correspondence, the president’s first and last names should never appear. The address should read: [4] X Research source The President The White House 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W. Washington, DC 20500.

steps.title: Begin your letter:
steps.content: Begin your letter: “Dear Mr./Madam President.” This is the polite and expected salutation with which all written addresses to the president should begin. [5] X Research source Do not use the president’s name in your correspondence. Continue to refer to them as Mr. or Madam President.

steps.title: Conclude your letter, “Most respectfully.”
steps.content: Conclude your letter, “Most respectfully.” This complimentary close will indicate that the body of your letter has concluded. [6] X Research source You can write thank you if you request something in the letter. [7] X Research source Sign and print your name at the end of the letter.

steps.title: Make your envelope out to “The Honorable” former president.
steps.content: Make your envelope out to “The Honorable” former president. Former presidents do not keep the title of “president” once they leave office (contrary to how they’re often referred to in the media). If you’re writing a letter to a former president, the envelope should be addressed to: “The Honorable [first and last name].” [8] X Research source For example, you could address a letter to “The Honorable Jimmy Carter” or “The Honorable George Bush.”

steps.title: Address written correspondence to “Dear Mr” and their surname.
steps.content: Address written correspondence to “Dear Mr” and their surname. A letter to a former president is slightly less formal than correspondence to a sitting president since the recipient no longer holds the office of president. Do not use the term “honorable” in the introduction or body of your correspondence—“honorable” should be used on the envelope only. [9] X Research source So, your letter would begin: “Dear Mr. Carter” or “Dear Mr. Bush.”

steps.title: Address a former president as “Mr.”
steps.content: Address a former president as “Mr.” and their surname in person. An in-person address will also be less formal for a former president than it would for a sitting president. For example, you would address Barack Obama as “Mr. Obama,” not as “Mr. President.” [10] X Research source The rules about introductions are similarly less formal. As a general sign of respect, though, it’s still probably best to introduce a third party to the former president.
